Award.AwardTitle: 48th Annual Orthopedic Research Society (ORS) Musculoskeletal Biology Workshop; Sun Valley, Idaho; July 24-28, 2019

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Sun Valley Workshop on Musculoskeletal Biology emphasizes active participation of junior faculty and students/fellows. Funds from this award will support competitive travel awards for junior investigators who will be able to present their research to a multidisciplinary audience and network with leaders in the field. Travel award recipients will also participate in one-on-one mentoring with senior investigators. The workshop will be organized around problem solving and extensive discussion, rather than just presentation. The meeting will include a program to highlight posters presented at the workshop: "Blue Ribbon Sun Valley Posters." Ten posters will be chosen for 3 minute summary presentations by the authors. The intent is to highlight the most significant posters, in many cases young investigator posters, and generate interest in visiting the posters. Career and professional development sessions, including "Navigating the FDA" and "Career Transitions: Planning and Negotiating for Career Advancement," are planned.

The musculoskeletal system (muscles, tendon, bone) is highly sensitive to mechanical load, and many younger investigators from previous Sun Valley meetings have submitted applications to the Biomechanics and Mechanobiology program. This workshop continues as one of the important training venues for future scientists in the area of mechanobiology of the musculoskeletal system based on its unique problem solving focus and the multidisciplinary group of participants.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The objective of the Sun Valley Workshop is to improve understanding across the many disciplines that study musculoskeletal biology, to provide new perspectives that lead to prevention and/or treatment of musculoskeletal diseases, and to develop interdisciplinary collaborations, especially for younger scientists and scientists new to the field. The workshop receives support from the NIH, NSF, and ASBMR.

 In 2019, it was the 48th Sun Valley Workshop and the 53rd year since the first Workshop was held in 1965. The theme of the 2019 Workshop was “New approaches to musculoskeletal tissue regeneration, quality, and targeting.” Sessions addressed significant current problems, potential limitations and solutions, and approaches applicable to both clinical and basic science, and applicable to both young investigators entering the field and established investigators looking for updates of the current scientific knowledge. The program also reflected the efforts towards addressing problems beyond bone and covering other tissues of the musculoskeletal system.

Sessions were: 1. Targeting drugs and cells to musculoskeletal tissues; 2. Tendon biology and disease; 3. Epigenetics and musculoskeletal disease; 4. Rare diseases of phosphate handling and tissue mineralization: too much or too little; 5. Major Methodologies: Material properties and tissue quality: state of the art; and 6.            Musculoskeletal regenerative medicine meets the clinic.

 Thirty-three posters were presented at the Workshop, including posters from the Young Investigator Awardees. Three separate sessions were devoted to oral presentations from the 10 winners of the ASBMR/Harold M. Frost Awards, and 3 sessions to the 10 Blue Ribbon Sun Valley Poster presentations. A total of 25 awards for junior investigators were given; all investigators presented their work from the podium or in a poster setting. Awards included 14 Alice L. Jee Memorial Travel Awards (including three to under-represented minority participants); 10 ASBMR/Harold M. Frost Awards; and 1 young investigator award in honor of Dr. Charles Turner.

 The Career Development session geared toward junior investigators, chaired by Marjolein van der Meulen, focused on “Career Transitions: Planning and Negotiating for Career Advancement.” It included transitioning from mentee to mentor; resources: start up and facilities, budgets, personnel; staffing a lab which included recruiting graduate students, technicians, staff, and post docs; maintaining your own projects and collaborating successfully; considerations and concerns: intangibles and other considerations; and transitions within industry. There were 35 attendees at this session, with approximately 50% postdoctoral fellows and 50% junior faculty.

 Continuing a tradition of mentorship, lunches between young investigators and senior investigators were arranged for all Award winners. All invited speakers were required to serve as mentors, and several senior investigators who attended to the meeting but were not speakers were also recruited as mentors. As an additional aspect of mentorship, we appointed a pre-workshop investigator mentor, who worked prior to the Workshop with the young investigators on content and length of their presentations. In addition, we continued the Blue Ribbon Poster and Presentation program in which selected posters were highlighted by 3 min-oral presentations to highlight work of young investigators and increased exposure of their work.

 We continue to be committed to equal participation of women in the Workshop. In 2019, 36% of the participants were women, 1 of 5 (20%) of Session Chairs was a woman, 3 of the 8 members of the Advisory Board are women, and 1 of the 2 co-Chairs of the workshop is a woman. In 2019, 8% of the participants were under-represented minorities including 1 African-American and 3 Hispanic. For the 2019, we continued to support URMs with young investigator and travel awards.  We reached out investigators labs personally to make them aware that there were at least 5 awards available only to URMs in addition to young investigator awards that are open to any young investigator including URM. 

 These are some of the comments received for the 2019 meeting:

  1. I am really glad I attended and got to meet many of the researchers whose work I have read
  2. This was a wonderful meeting. I am a trainee who has attended ASBMR the last three years. This workshop fostered a completely different type of discussion, and I felt like trainees could comfortably ask basic questions as well as interact with some leaders of the bone research field. 
  3. All the talks were cutting-edge. Great workshop
  4. Excited for the net. Hope the conference remains the same!
  5. Great meeting!
  6. The discussion aspect is my favorite part of the workshop and in the talks where the discussion was very active this was fantastic. Excellent meeting
  7. Content diverse and of high quality
  8. Outstanding organization and program. Well done. Best meeting I attended this year.

 Respectfully submitted,

 Teresita Bellido, PhD

Co-Chair, Sun Valley Workshop on Musculoskeletal Biology
